It is a small shape puzzle and was created to challenge very young minds.

Objectives:They should expect to learn fine motor skills and shape recognition.
Audiences: I would expect that kids in preschool or lower could benefit from using this tool.
Preparation: To use this puzzle you don't really need to know much and you have all the recourses you need.
My idea was for children preschool or lower to use this tool to refine their fine motor skills by putting the shapes in to the holes. This also helps with shape recognition because you can only put the specific shape in to its specific hole which makes you start to recognize the shapes.
when you are finish with the puzzle you should expect to recognize shapes a little better but if you want bigger results you want to repeat doing the puzzle.

So I thought it would be cool to have a set of bird houses that you could use to spell out something with in your backyard.  Each Letter is made up of a housing and a removable snap in face and all of them have entrance holes made up from the gaps in the letters.  The exception for that is the L and the T, which have entrance holes on the sides, because reasons.  They all have holes for ventilation on the sides and mounting at the back.  You can also mount them using the hooks on the top.  The zip contains all 52 files, 26 houses, and 26 faces.  
I had a lot of fun designing these, even though it was extremely tedious at times.  I'm happy with how most of them came out, but I think that there will always be a few are never quite right.  Anyway, if you like it, please let me know.  Thanks!

title: Tree Design Spinning Ring (Customizable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spinning ring, inspired by AmazingSpanoMan's "Customizable Fidget Spinner Ring". I liked his design, but I wanted to add some constraints:
  • It should be look like a regular ring, thin and discreet enough for daily wear,
  • There should be no exposed ridges that would rub against adjacent fingers,
  • The bearing should seem to fit tightly, but
  • It should still spin freely (after wearing down imperfections in the print).
    • I also wanted to add a tree design for Christmas. This design fills those requirements. I've been wearing one for a few weeks, and it's been a real hit! I have successfully printed this ring from 14mm to 22mm diameter (US size 3 - 12 3/4) at 8 or 9 mm (axial) thickness. Going larger shouldn't be a problem, although the smallest rings are difficult to assemble. If you don't want any trees on your ring, just set the "Number of Trees" to 0. (Or wait for me to publish the "No Design" version.) Give it a try!

Printer:

Rapide Lite 200 v1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm (recommended)

Infill:

100%

Notes: Sliced with Cura, printed in PLA. My best results came from printing with an 0.1mm resolution, although it can also be printed at 0.2 for fitting samples.

After printing, you'll want to clean up the print a little bit, just enough to make sure there aren't whiskers or bumps on the inner ring, or the inside of the outer ring.
The most challenging part is getting the two parts to snap together without breaking the outside ring. I have had to press the rings together onto a flat surface in some cases. Try putting the outer ring on tree-tops-first, to minimize the risk of breaking the thinnest part of the ring.
Small imperfections will be ground away if you press the parts together and spin them after assembly. The ring will spin more freely with use.

I designed the bearing shape as a sketch in 123D Design, and rotated it to make a ring.
After a few iterations to get the basic bearing shape right, I focused on reducing the (radial) thickness of the ring until it was very comfortable to wear.
Bringing the design into OpenSCAD allowed me to make an adjustable design. I modified the parameters exposed in the Customizer to get the bearing as tight as possible, and to generate rings of many sizes with little work.
Once in OpenSCAD, it was also easy to add a tree design cutout on the outer ring.

Customization Make sure to experiment with the Advanced Options if you want to change the ring's size or the size of the tree design. If you print a small ring, reduce the number of trees to improve its chances of surviving assembly. Troubleshooting If you are having trouble getting the rings to stick to the raft, you may need to experiment with "Thinnest Layer" in Advanced Options. If you are having trouble assembling or spinning the ring, you may need to experiment with the "Bearing" settings in Advanced Options. Licensing You are granted a Creative Commons Atribution-Non-Commercial-ShareAlike License. If you upload your design to Thingiverse, please use the "Remix" feature. If you upload your design elsewhere, please link to this page or pikaworx.com. I reserve the right to negotiate special licensing.

title: Anathema Cosplay Staff from World of Warcraft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have made this staff for cosplay at an event called “JapanAniManga night". The designing in the 3d program, printing, building and painting took around half a year.  It is almost 1.8 meters in length. A special detail I payed attention to are the green crystals, they are hollow with LEDs inside and glow beautifully at night.
The staff was my first own 3d project. I have previously never really worked with a 3d program. I've drawn the whole thing with Google Sketch Up. I bought my Ultimaker2 for this project, so I did not have any experience with 3d printing as well. Therefore, there may be a few parts that need slight adjustments after printing to fit together better. I had to sharpen some edges, use glue etc. to put it together correctly.
Inside the lower part of the staff is a carbon rod with a 1 cm diameter and a length of 1m. The carbon rod made the whole staff a lot more stable. I had to create extra fixations and glued them inside the staff to make the staff durable enough to carry it around all day.
On the assembly itself:
I put the staff together from bottom to top after I printed all parts (see picture with named parts).
In component 2, I placed a screw through the cover and fixed with a small nut. I glued a small magnet to the lid and this way I had a way to close the lid and keep it closed.
Inside that lid is a 9V battery, and it’s connected to the 14 LEDs placed in all the crystals throughout the staff. 
Component 9 was hard to fixate and used a lot of glue, since it held the whole upper part of the staff.
After component 8 and 9 I made the upper part of the staff only one half at the time, so I could put all the power lanes and LED’s inside them fist. 
Component 9 has 6 small LED in 3 x 2 pairs, Number 18 has 1 large 8 mm LED with 360° beam angle, the crystal Number 16 (printed twice) and Number 21 use 6 small LEDs together. 
To fix all wires in place I used a little bit glue. 
After all LED's and cable were placed I glued the both halves together. 
Tips on printing: Since it was my first 3d project I designed myself I had to fix quite a lot after printing.
I had to readjust some corners of printed parts since they sometimes raised themselves while printing. With a heat gun I readjusted them where needed. I had to patch up the pieces where I glued them together and grinded off the glue to make them look neat
I painted the Crystals (1, 9, 16, 18 and 21) with a liquid silicone to protect them while painting the surface of the rest of the staff. Then I painted a transparent matte finish on the whole staff to protect it a bit from scratches etc.
Print settings are written in the title of the parts and some parts need additional supports.

author: mcruz24

title: Mendel X-Axis Belt Modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After having backlash problems on my RepRap Mendel X-axis and getting sick of the awkward round-4-corners belt path, I decided to give it a re-design, in the hope of shortening the belt to take up some slack while simplifying the construction. These brackets make the belt-path compatible with carriages intended for Prusa Mendel. I have included an adapter bracket that allows it to still be used with the original Mendel X-Carriage when necessary, however the idler bearing and pulley need to be spaced quite far out from the plastic parts in order to keep the belt parallel to the X-axis, with a full nut and a washer or two in the case of the bearing.
I hope someone will design something like the OpenX Carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6278) but compatible with this, so that a 624-bearing-based carriage can be used with the Prusa-style belt-path, that is if I don't design one first. I have also included an optional second idler bearing bracket to go directly next to the motor bracket, so that the belt turns slightly less of a sharp angle as it goes round the pulley, hopefully reducing belt wear, though I really don't think it's necessary.
The big circular holes in the motor & idler2 brackets are there to allow ventilation around the X-motor, so that PLA parts don't heat up too much. (I wanted test parts to be biodegradeable in case I messed up) N.B. I have updated the files for the main brackets at either end as I found a couple of weaknesses in my first prototypes where I cut away excess corner material too liberally and found that the slots for m3 captive nuts shrank more than I thought they would, making it difficult to fit them. They should also be easier to print now.

The idler is designed such that you should be able to fit the belt in whatever clamps you want easily, then adjust the tension by pulling the bearing back before tightening the nut(s) securing it. By using this as opposed to http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel_Alternate_X_Motor_Bracket you will save:
4x 624 Bearings
4x M4x15/20 Bolts
4x M4 Nylock Nuts
12x M3x20/25 Bolts
12x M3 Nylock Nuts
and associated washers While using an additional:
1x 608 Bearing
M8x40mm Studding
3x M8 Washers
2-3x M8 Full Nuts
2x M8 Mudguard/Penny Washers (or a printed pulley)
7x M3x10 Bolt
8x M3 Full Nut (All 8 bolts & captive nuts are not strictly necessary) and if you use the adapter for the original x-carriage:
Replace 4x M4x40 bolts each with 1 washer and full nut with -
2-4x M4x35 bolts + washers & full nuts (all 4 not necessary)
4x M4x25/30 bolts
4x M4 Nylock Nuts
8x M4 Washers

comments.text:
Cheers, I'm just trying to design up an all-in one version that re-uses some parts, since I think my Z-axis trapped nuts are finally wearing out after many months of use, and the assembly of the remaining bits of Sells' x-axis are quite awkward to dis-assemble and re-assemble.
I do like how he used parallel 624's on one side of each axis to prevent binding from imperfectly fitting smooth rods, but if I build another CNC machine I think I'll keep that part and use linear bearings or bushings on the 3-bearing side.

This reel holder uses two cones with integrated bearing that will take both thrust and vertical load.   
The cones are not resting on the reel holder shaft, but "floating" around the shaft, held in place by the reel holder bearing thrust face in both horizontal and vertical direction.   
This eliminates the need for a bearing on the shaft and also reduces friction. You can manually adjust the how freely the reel is spinning by the nut at the end.

All parts were sliced with Cura_13.6.04 and printed with PLA The groove in the bearing cone is designed for 18 off 6 mm BB's. I recommend that you level your build plate especially before printing the two bearing cones. Doing so will save you some sanding of the groove for the BB's. Common Print settings: Layer Height: 0.1
Infill: 30% The reel holder was printed with support everywhere and raft. The cone bearing was printed with support. The cone bearing groove has tight fit against the BB's, so you will most likely have to sand the groove a bit in order to get the ball to run freely. I used P180 sandpaper (180 grains per cm^2) The balls are pressed into the grove, you will hear a "click" and the balls will be held in place by the groove walls. Don't insert all the balls after it's printed. Insert just one and run it around the groove to see if it's snagging anywhere. I have shown how I did it in one of the pictures attached.

remixed_from.title: Fan duct and Mini Differential IR sensor v1.1 mount for E3Dv6 hot end on Kossel

title: Fan duct and Mini Differential IR sensor mount for E3Dv6 hot end with commonly used mounting plate

description.text: I made the original fan duct to fit a delta - but then I decided that I didn't like deltas! I then made some modifications so that it would fit my existing Prusa i3 and a new recently built CoreXY. This meant changing the mounting plate from "Kossel effector" to "standard 50mm spaced M4 holes", as found under a Gregs' Wade Extruder (and also used on many printers). I also increased the diameter of the fan hole slightly to reduce air resistance. The main reason for using this mount is that I wanted to use dc42's IR sensor, with the bonus of getting rid of the original E3Dv6 cooling fan mount, which I consider the only weak part of the design (mine always got loose, and rattled around). I have included the files for 2 types of duct - one for the v1.0 version of the IR sensor, and the other for the smaller v1.1 version. Note that I mount the sensor's PCB on the front of the mounting lugs instead of the back as originally designed; this is to move the board a bit further away from the hot-end. In addition I mounted a thin sheet of stainless steel (wrapped in kapton tape) on the back of the lugs as an extra heat deflector. I have also included files for a spacer plate, but that is only required if you want to fit the fan mount to a G&C CoreXY printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003119). Apologies for the poor pictures of this piece - it's very hard to get a good one when it's mounted on a printer, surrounded by lots of bits and pieces! Many thanks to the original designers of this mount - my modifications are trivial compared to their work!

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.3

Infill:

30% - 40%

Notes: I printed mine using ABS, with the mount plate downwards (I used a brim). It is fairly easy to remove the support which, in my prints, only appeared in the fan chamber. The E3Dv6 is a VERY tight fit on the mounting plate - I had to scrape the plastic a bit before I could slide the hot-end fully into the slot. It's best to maintain a tight fit, to avoid any wobble. You should be able to mount the 40mm fan using M3 screws (don't drill out the holes before fitting). Note that you will still need something above this part to locate the top of the E3Dv6, just as with any other mounting plate. This may be the bottom of the extruder, or some part of the X carriage bracket.

description.text:
During December Six Flags and a lot of other theme parks sell necklaces of full sized battery-powered C9 (I think they're C9s) lights that flash as souvenirs for their holiday festivities (I say holiday because not everyone celebrates Christmas: The corporate holiday that includes awkward dinners and gift openings with family members and follows Black Eye Friday and Hallow(een)/Empty Wallet Day). I asked the vendor how much they were: $12!!! I think I'll save those $12 and use what I have at home to get something even better. That's were these files come in. I mocked up the base and bulb of the lights and to light them I used the 60LED/m WS2812B addressable LEDs commonly sold as DotStars™ or NeoPixels™. I cut up 10 individual LEDs, tined them on all sides, and re-soldered them with about 2 inches in between (2.5 inches for 1/4 inch of stripped wire on each side) of 3 wire ribbon cable. I daisy-chained them into the proper locations (output->input) and the first input to D1 of an Adafruit Gemma. Gemmas can handle up to about 100 sets 3 LEDS(red,green,blue) so 10 should be no problem. Edit the 'strandtest' program on the Arduino IDE by changing the pixel number to 10 and the output pin to 1 (not D1). Do all this while printing the bases and bulbs. Print the bases first at twice the size (the original file is too small for the width of the light FlexPCB) and string them through the hole onto the lights first pushing them all the way to the end and then solder all 10 lights together and slide and hot glue a base to each light. Paint the bases black or dark green. Paint, tape or heat-shrink the wires to cover them up (you can use anything just cover any exposed wires. Next, add any functions you want, flash the Gemma with the program and connect any back-up cell phone charger with a 5V at least 0.5A output. Then connect to power via the same mini USB you used to program the Gemma. You can also plug these into the wall with a cell phone charger or into your laptop or into the USB charging port in your car (if you have one). Finally sit back, relax and enjoy your little string of programmed lights. Enjoy the show!
Any sized show is a show. The string could be one bulb or hundreds of bulbs. ---Update---
I've now include the mostly custom and fully tested Gemma Sketch. This will work with any Arduino or Arduino compatible device just make sure everything is in order to run the sketch. Disclaimer: By downloading the sketch, you take FULL responsibility to all effects of the sequence which includes strobing and bright light values. Use responsibly.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

Notes: Print the bases twice the scale because alone they are too small... The bulbs are fine, print them as is...
See the WS2812B and Gemma soldering instructions in the Summary...
Autodesk 123D Design Free Version, patience, and the determination to make something better than a $12 light necklace that will stop working as soon as I leave the park I bought it from.

Replacement Hand Crank for a "B&D Workmate" early model.
My workmate was bought in the 1980's and is almost 100% metal with a wood top. It is similar to the Black & Decker 21321 model or WM425. The swivel-clamp-pegs and the hand cranks are plastic.
One of my hand cranks broke and epoxy didn't fix it so I took the measurements and designed a replacement. The replacement I designed now has a double handle but it's easy to delete the second crank from the OpenScad file if you want it more like the original. I believe the double crank will give better leverage to really tighten the clamp and loosen it again. I also thickened up the crank and head quite a bit, and added some reinforcement since a printed part isn't as durable as a molded part. The critical dimensions should be the same. The angles are changed to make it easier to print but that shouldn't matter much.

My takeoffs were done with care but until I fit it to the machine I won't know for sure. If you have a different model please check your dimensions carefully they are probably different. EDIT:The dimensions are good and fit is fine. BUT, the Pins are not strong enough printed vertically and broke when stressed. I printed them separately and horizontally with support turned on. They printed well and are strong enough now.
An m10x40 bolt may work if the pins are omitted. The model isn't completely parametric unless you delete or modify the "reinforcement cones" on the crank. They were a quick and dirty HACK. The rest of the design should be parametric.

I have a lot of problems using PLA on my printer - while looking around for a solution, I stumbled upon: http://creatrtips.freeforums.org/lubrication-egg-pla-add-on-t66.html Not having a Kinder Egg to hand, I decided to roll my own variant. The major advantage it has is that you can squirt additional WD40 into the sponge through the grills in the top. Working brilliantly :). Keptone on the base, 40 degrees on the bed, 210 degrees on the nozzle. Played with extrusion multiplier a bit (ended up with 1.1 on my printer as results were springy and threaded).

No special instructions to print - no support needed of course. Cut a bit of sponge to fit the box, then cut that in half so that the filament can be threaded through the two holes, lubricate the sponge with WD40 and give it a try. If you want to customise it, this might work: http://openjscad.org/#http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=YhvUqVyS Requires Chrome or Firefox. Any generated STL will probably require fixing via netfabb or similar.

author: buckeyebillbear

description.text:
Merry Christmas to all!
This is a project done by my boyfriend and I. these are the LED we used: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015QNRO2W?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00 day 1: Santa hat
day 2: Cupcake
day 3: Piston
day 4: Gingerbread man (icing made with ABS acetone paste)
day 5: Chinese food box (thing:17629)
day 6: Candy cane (made with red ribbon)
day 7: Chinese lantern (windows are made with vellum paper)
day 8: Snowman
day 9: Gift box
day 10: Stocking
day 11: LEM
day 12: the Moon (thing:14011)
day 13: Jumping jack Santa

You will need to print two of each tree A1, tree A2, tree B1, tree B2, and star. Tree parts are meant to be glued or welded together, including the ornament hooks.
All the sticks for the ornaments like the cherry stem and piston pin are made directly with 1.75mm filament.
The small flag is for the LEM and the bigger one is for the moon.
Please feel free to ask any questions!

comments.text: I would love to see at least the tree in a EPS or SVG or DXF vector file format for us poor folks that have or use a Laser cutter....
comments.author: Greymantalker

comments.text: Poor folks? My Anet was $150 bucks. I can't afford a laser cutter
comments.author: Greymantalker

comments.text: Hi! Thanks for making this model; it's awesome. I was wondering where in the zip file the biggest and smallest tree arches were? I can't seem to find them in the file. Thank you.
comments.author: Mizu4thewin

comments.text: Sorry for the late reply. It seems like I missed a couple files. It's been a while so I need to dig through my computer to find them. If you don't want to wait for that, the first file has all the pieces of the tree, if you put that in cura and split them, you can delete the rest and leaves only the ones you want.
comments.author: Mizu4thewin

comments.text: Oh, don't worry about the late reply. It's fine. This is the reason I start on my presents early. :) Thank you for looking for the files. I really appreciate it. Also, thank you for the alternative solution. Have a great day.

title: Napkin Ring and Knurled Knob Customizer

description.text:
EDIT (17 Dec 2015): Clarified 'twist' and made it easier to get the right values You want to create a knurled ring or knob for your rotary dial? This is the solution for you! or You want to snazz-up that dining experience? Get the wife-acceptance factor (WAF)? Print out some of your own design twisted and knurled napkin rings! Maybe even try one of those nice pastel colours that she likes so much. This customiser allows you to create knurled and modern looking rings and caps, I have put in a photo of a couple of samples of what you can do with it. You choose:
  • Size
  • Shape (number of sides)
  • How many twists / how much detail
  • Patterned or circular hole or cap it off, it's your choice!
    • In my example I have printed a knurled knob for the rotary dial on my printer, it's got 120deg twists and 8-sides. 12.7mm wide, 17mm long and has a 6mm hole. Fits nicely on my Reprap discount LCD. Watch a video of it printing here:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZhVNJG5n5yg

description.text: This key is an artistic depiction of an antique key. Although the key does not open any physical doors, it symbolizes the key to opening the door to success and opportunities. It is made on the Makerbot. The door to life is there, go unlock it!

I used inventor to create the key. The main steps were creating an elipse as the top of the key, and a rectangular bottom. The pieces were then extruded roughly .75 in. In the makerbot program, the key was laid flat on the center of the platform.
I didn't run into any problems creating the design, or in printing.

title: Spinning Ring (Customizable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spinning ring, inspired by AmazingSpanoMan's "Customizable Fidget Spinner Ring".
It's based on my [Christmas Tree Design Ring], but without any design. This is more discreet, can be printed shorter (axial), and can be worn in months other than December.

Printer:

Rapide Lite 200 v1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Sliced with Cura, printed in PLA. My best results came from printing with an 0.1mm resolution, although it can also be printed at 0.2 for fitting samples.

After printing, you'll want to clean up the print a little bit, just enough to make sure there aren't whiskers or bumps on the inner ring, or the inside of the outer ring.
The most challenging part is getting the two parts to snap together without breaking the outside ring. I have had to press the rings together onto a flat surface in some cases.
Small imperfections will be ground away if you press the parts together and spin them after assembly. The ring will spin more freely with use.

I designed the bearing shape as a sketch in 123D Design, and rotated it to make a ring.
After a few iterations to get the basic bearing shape right, I focused on reducing the (radial) thickness of the ring until it was very comfortable to wear.
Bringing the design into OpenSCAD allowed me to make an adjustable design. I modified the parameters exposed in the Customizer to get the bearing as tight as possible, and to generate rings of many sizes with little work.

Troubleshooting If you are having trouble getting the rings to stick to the raft, you may need to experiment with "Thinnest Layer" in Advanced Options. If you are having trouble assembling or spinning the ring, you may need to experiment with the "Bearing" settings in Advanced Options. Licensing You are granted a Creative Commons Atribution-Non-Commercial-ShareAlike License. If you upload your design to Thingiverse, please use the "Remix" feature. If you upload your design elsewhere, please link to this page or pikaworx.com. I reserve the right to negotiate special licensing.

These parts are used to construct an Open Sim Wheel (OSW) kit from Ollie Aina.  There are three parts:  Back Panel, IONI and Voltage Regulator bracket, and Power Supply bracket.

Printer:

OpenBuilds Pegasus 8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: There's nothing particularly difficult to print on these parts. I printed the Back Panel in PLA, but used PETG for the other two. The interior of the case shouldn't get too hot, so PLA should be fine as well, I was just playing with some new filament.

Back Panel The back panel has various other parts inserted. The fuse and switch are part of the Ollie Kit. Next is a Neutrik plug and a USB A-B plug, with B on the outside and A on the inside. The upper right is made for a 2-row D-Sub 15 connector, I used a solder connector. The lower right are two XT60 plugs for the enable and e-stop. The plugs I got for this have tabs on them so they can be screwed down. I got them from Hobbyking, http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__81603__XT60_Connector_Male_Female_with_Lock_and_Insulating_Cap_5_pairs_.html. Just make sure to snap off the locking tabs or you'll not be able to unplug the connectors after you plug them in.

The tree models will need support. To print this without lights, print tree-cutout.stl, and you don't need to print base.stl or tree-flat-bottom.stl. The star will need to be glued on top. To print with lights, print tree-flat-bottom.stl, and base.stl, tree-cutout.stl isn't needed.
Print the tree with 0% infill. Cura needed to print the bottom layers or the upper tiers wouldn't attach.
I had to take a razor blade and carefully cut off the bottom few layers to get access to the inside of the tree.
The grey/blue blobs on the inside is JB plastic weld, I broke off a few tiers when removing support. For the lights, I used 2 LEDs and a 100 ohm resistor in series and put about 5 sets of those in parallel connected to a USB cable. It pulls around 30mA for me, so well below usb's power limits. To light up the star I heated up a 3/16" drill bit with a lighter and drilled in the very top to allow a led to poke and shine through to the star. The star will need to be glued on top.(Hot glue/welders/goop will allow the led to shine through still) Once the LEDs are in the tree and the top is lit, the tree just rests on the stand/base.
I used a little more JB plastic weld to hold it together.

Printer:

Rigidbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

description.text:

It helps avoid the XDS100 PCB touching the proto circuit, and also protects the rather fragile USB input which is easy to shear off the PCB. The case part of this is a remix however I can't locate the original. The hastily designed slide-in faceplate was done in DesignCAD 3D.
Prints easily in PLA - it's a tight squeeze due to the XDS100 PCB snap-offs. File them if you need to.

The model was created in Autodesk Inventor 2011, using only 90 degree angles to maintain its rigid appearance. It was designed to stand up on a desk or computer, and was inspired by the increasing popular game called Minecraft. Additionally, the design was meant to test the makerbot. The Creeper is a close to exact scale model of the one in the game. It was supposed to have 4 legs instead of 2 but I decided to have 2 because it would be more structurally strong. Due to the laws of physics, the original print didn't turn out exactly as i wanted it to. As you can see by the attached images, the mouth sagged a bit because the Makerbot was forced to extrude the plastic in mid air (as it prints layer by layer). I then refined the original design to prevent this from happening by increasing the width of the bottom of the mouth.

Since the Creeper is only one part, the instructions are fairly simple.
  • Download the STL file.
  • Generate the G-Code for the part.
  • Print the part
  • Remove from platform and enjoy!

description.text: A small mobile robot by FabLab Digital Projects. The robot is based on ATmega328, MOSFET Transistors, Stepper motors, 9V battery and Bluetooth Module (Sparkfun BT Mate Gold).

Step 4. Bend the frame using the heatgun.
Step 5. Put everything on the frame.
Step 6. Program the robot with Sparkfun FTDI Basic/Sparkfun FTDI Cable.

An obscure need, I will admit! We ordered some roller blinds, but the windows we have (made by Anlin) slide left-to-right and right-to-left, and the hand-grips have edges that look like they could cut into the blinds. These pieces are just rounded blocks that fit on the ends of the hand-grips so that the hand grips do not cut into the blinds as they roll down. 
This is for the right-hand panel. You'll have to mirror it for the left-hand side.

description.text:
CAUTION WORK IN PROGRESS! WORKS AS IS THOUGH
This was a custom mount as I wanted the camera to be somewhat hidden so it wasn't in the way of my viewing live, but still wanted a good birds eye view of the print. I origionally intended the camera mount to be like the one in the picture you see now, however I have changed it just a tad and mounted it upside down making it more discrete and compact. I will post pictures soon I am doing a test print to see how well it shows and what kind of view it has. This is MUCH better than most others out there and it integrates it into the case and isn't seen.
I am currently working on a Pi 2 case to shorten the length of cable required. Right now I am using a 75cm/750mm 15 pin ribbon cable but you could get away with a 50cm/500mm. I plan on making a setup to use the standard cable that comes with the waveshare/raspicam cameras, reducing the probability of noise in the picture due to length of cable. You could use the metal type rings (I forget the technical name) to help. But for now, I have no noise and is working great.
Any other ideas or suggestions, feel free to share, I will try to accommodate any request!
Thanks and hope you all enjoy!

I used 15 due to size, it seems perfect.

Notes: All other parts you will NOT need any rafts or supports, however, the piece that mounts to the frame of the FFCP, you will need supports, and they peel off very easily and it works great! Other than that, pretty straight forward.

You will need;
Double sided tape
Allen bolt 3mx18mm or longer with nut
15 pin ribbon cable atleast 50cm/500mm That's pretty much it besides a case that your Pi sits in. I have mine double sided taped to the case of the pi, left side under the carrying hole. Run the cable through there and down to the pi. Soon, that will all change and the pi will be mounted under the printer with the PSU. I am working on a small PCB to supply power and drop it to 5V from 24V and output 3amp 5v power to supply not only the pi and camera, but also a 3.5" or 5" HDMI Touch LCD

description.text: corgi

title: Koch Snowflake Ornament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Koch Snowflake Ornament I wanted to make an ornament to give to relatives and friends this Christmas, like some crocheted ornaments I've received in the past. To make this feasible, I needed a quick-printing and relatively sturdy design. I also wanted something mathematically interesting. Inspired by SimonFront's Koch Snowflake, especially the way that it used multiple iterations of the fractal to make a single design, I decided to rethink his design for spiralized printing on FDM printers. They print very quickly, so make a lot and share them this Christmas! They should scale very easily in Cura, if you want a whole blizzard of various flakes. Each object is a stack of Koch Snowflakes with different number of iterations from n to 1. For instance, "Koch 3" has 3 iterations on the bottom, 2 iterations in the middle, and 1 iteration on top. This gives the object a little bit of depth and interest, and also helps it keep its shape. I printed these with glow-in-the-dark filament. "Koch 3" and "Koch 4" are pictured. It is easier to see the pattern in "Koch 3", but "Koch 4" looks more "fluffy", and so it is my custom Christmas ornament for this year. "Koch 5" is unlikely to work very well unless you scale it up or print with a smaller shell size. If you do make one, please share a photo! For more information on the Koch Snowflake fractal, see Wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koch_snowflake

Printer:

Rapide Lite 200 v1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes: Sliced with Cura, using the "Spiralize the outer contour" and "Only follow mesh surface" options. I used 0.8mm shell thickness, and 100% Initial layer line width.

I wrote the Koch Curve generation code in simple LOGO. I converted that into a Python script that used the built-in turtle graphics module to draw the curves and export them as SVG files. Here's the graphical output of the script in action (with annotations and freeze frames for clarity): https://youtu.be/fxdeNtVfa2E Using svg2pdf and pstoedit, I converted the SVG files to DXF that could be imported into OpenSCAD. In OpenSCAD, I imported each DXF file in turn, fixed its aspect ratio, and extruded it to its proper height.

Gcode Customization Since these print so quickly (6-7 minutes for "Koch 4", 3 minutes for "Koch 3"), I modified Cura's gcode to leave the extruder and bed heaters running at the end of a print. This allows me to make 6-8 "Koch 4" snowflakes per hour, depending on how quickly I get up to clear the bed, and how long Octoprint takes to reset after each print. This does mean that I can't go too far away, as the printer won't cool down. I kept a second version of the gcode file that does shut down the heaters, and I use that for the last print in a series. If you upload your design elsewhere, please link to this page or pikaworx.com. I reserve the right to negotiate special licensing.

title: Cards Against Humanity unofficial card holder

description.text:
I found that holding ten Cards Against Humanity cards while attempting to drink heavily lead to using two hands, which interfered greatly with my ability to drink heavily. So with this stand I can hold the most likely 4 or 5 in one hand, put the 5 or 6 long-shots / highly situational cards into the stand, and continue drinking uninterrupted. Would probably also work for one-handed smoking of various plant-based substances.
You would only need the clip if the leg is on the extreme edges of the rails. I have the legs about 1/4 of the way up, as seen in the photos, and the clip isn't needed. 
It's designed to stack cards continuously if they are 2 lines of text tall. If you get a 3 or more-liner, skip a notch, or place that one in the bottom. Like in the photo.
It's easiest to load the cards from the top down, especially after a few drinks (or whatever).
the "leg with rafts" is for those who might experience some corners pulling up while printing the "leg", which I get on my Robo3D even with lots of glue stick, and don't want to use the raft function of their software which would put a raft everywhere....

This is a diffuser/baffle for the exhaust port on a ShopVac-style vacuum. Instead of the air blowing out in a straight stream that kicks up dust/etc, this thing will redirect the flow in all directions, and create some turbulence, so that you can hardly feel it just a few inches from the port. The holes in the part surface add up to roughly 1.5x the area of the exhaust port, so this diffuser should not cause any back-pressure. The sound coming out of my vac does not change at all when I attach the part. I may have gone a bit overboard with all the internal flow-redirection, but it works really well! The attached STL is actually sized to fit a Home Depot Ridgid 60-litre Vac, which has a port that is roughly 2 1/4 inches diameter. You will need to scale that up/down to fit other vacuums. The tolerance is such that the part will not stay in on its own. Instead you wrap a strip of duct tape around the rim, and that will seal the gap and provide a tight fit (see photos). No support is necessary. I printed at the lowest quality on a Makerbot Rep2, in about 2 hours. There is a mouse-ear around the bottom to make sure it sticks, just snap that off or use an exacto. Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360. F3D archive is included if you want to improve the design.

HBumps strive to fill a need in the Lego compatible building community. Since the dawn of time (ok, since the dawn of Lego), builders have struggled to connect two pieces together back to back or front to front. HBumps ++ allow two pieces to be joined bottom to bottom,
while HBumps -- allow two pieces to be joined top to top. HBumps are a work in progress, it is likely that multiple size HBumps will be required dependent upon materials used for printing. Different plastics, metals, etc. have varying shrinkage rates, etc.

Just a recreation of the classic slide puzzle. When you solve the puzzle it comes together to make the ancient Chinese "Head of an Ogre" face. I've included blank tiles that you can put your own 3D relief images onto....
OR you can print the blank tiles as is and glue a regular 2D image to them.

Everything will require full supports except for Puzzle_bottom.STL!
Print Puzzle_bottom.STL and Puzzle_top.STL.

THEN DO ONE OF THE FOLLOW....

  • If you're going to use the Head of an Ogre, then just print Ogre_piece1.STL - Ogre_piece9.STL. I printed mine with a 0.3mm layer height, but it would probably look a lot better if you printed in 0.2mm or 0.1mm.

  • If you're going to glue on a 2D image, then print Blank_piece.STL 8 times and Blank_removable.STL once.
    You'll want your 2D image to be about 4.25 x 4.25 inches large.

  • If you're going to make a custom 3D image, then load Blank_piece.STL and Blank_removable.STL into your 3D modeling program, copy Blank_piece.STL so there are 8 total, and arrange them like this.
    • Then put your 3D image over it and cut it up using a plane cutter or whatever your 3D program might have.

Then put all the pieces together. I used #6 Machine Screws that were 1/2" long
and #6 hex nuts

description.text:
Edit: This case has been superseded by the squared off slim case, I highly recommend it over this older design. Edit: 17 April. Update to fit Dan Murray high gain antennas. Also long enough to fit a VK-172. Same deal as below regarding the hole patterns just look for the files labeled new. New version of the Nooelec RTL-SDR means a new smaller case. This version comes in several flavors depending on how many antennas you want to attach and if you want holes for suction cups or not. All versions use the same base. The base has a hole for an MCX-SMA bulkhead adapter. All versions of this case have minimal passive vents and have a cutout for a 30x30x10mm fan. All tops have mounts for a GPS/AHRS. RY835ai Choose which top you want. Each STL file is named depending on what options it has.
Two antenna versions have a hole for the extra SMA adapter.
One antenna versions do not have that hole.
Suction cup versions have 3 6.4mm (1/4") holes in the top for you to insert some suction cups. I got some suction cups with metal hooks at a local hardware store. They just need to have a mushroom head on the back with the thin part being 1/4". I use M3 cap head screws but #4 screws would work just fine. Start by drilling them top case holes to allow the hardware to slide in and then gently screw the screws into the base. https://www.shapeways.com/shops/rtd If you like this design and want to thank me my paypal address is [email protected] I can also do any customization.

remixed_from.author: PocketBrain
remixed_from.title: Storage handle screwdriver for magnetic chuck.

title: Improved storage handle screwdriver for magnetic chuck

description.text:
I decided to put bit storage in the handle of my storage-handle screwdriver (reference remixed design). In addition to the 3/16" magnet, you will need six 1/8" dia. x 1/16" magnets to retain the bits. I used some high-strength magnets so they retain the bits even when I dislodge the chuck with a tap to my palm. The diameter of this one is wider by a few millimeters; that was required to retain the bits and keep strength. When you have put this together and hear the bits snap into place for the first time, it is a happy sound!
Used for a 1/4" chuck that takes 1/4" bits. Next up: a parametric SCAD design. I already have the preliminary. :-)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

50% to 75%

Notes: Use 4 shells or more to give it good strength. I recommend ABS for this application.

• Ensure your print is loose enough to remove the chuck easily prior to inserting it completely! The handle storage area should be looser than the "business end."
  • To insert the 3/16" magnet, simply center it on the end of the chuck and insert fully into the screwdriver. The friction and pressure will retain the magnet.
  • To insert the small magnets, place them on the end of a small steel rod or long screwdriver bit or chuck; off-center if you're using a 1/4" hex. Note: you may need to glue the small magnets in place; use cyanoacrylate adhesive ("super glue") or a bit of thick ABS slurry.
  • Carry your most-used six (or seven) bits with the screwdriver.
  • When storing the bit in their handle slots, turn them so the hex face with the marking faces outward; you will be able to quickly tell a Ph1 from Ph2, etc.
  • You might want to take emory cloth/sandpaper to the edges, as I find they print a bit sharp. My old design wore smooth, so this is strictly optional, if you want it to be comfortable to use on day 1.
I used Autodesk 123D Design to make this.
